docs.lead_paragraph: Three years ago, Nicole E. Arzu was expecting her second child, but she received some tough news instead. Her doctors told her that her kidneys were not functioning properly. If she continued her pregnancy, they warned, her kidneys might cease processing toxins, her lungs could fill with fluid, and she could ultimately die in a way that sounded much like drowning. But Ms. Arzu felt fine, she said, and could not imagine giving up her pregnancy.

headline.main: The Neediest Cases; 'Weekend Mom' Gets the Full-Time Job

docs.abstract: Article on how New York Times Neediest Cases Fund has helped Nicole E Arzu, Brooklyn mother undergoing kidney dialysis; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Clearly emboldened by his strong second-place finish in the Iowa caucuses, Steve Forbes sought to use the Republican debate here tonight to put the front-runner, George W. Bush, on the defensive, arguing that Mr. Bush's record as governor of Texas was not as glowing as Mr. Bush portrays. Mr. Forbes was not the only one to criticize Mr. Bush, but his accusations that education in Texas had gotten worse and that government spending had increased under Mr. Bush seemed to hit the hardest. Mr. Bush paused for several seconds during his response.

headline.main: Forbes Challenges Bush On His Record in Texas

docs.abstract: Steve Forbes tries to use Republican presidential debate in Manchester, NH, to put front-runner, George W Bush, on defensive; contends that Bush's record as governor of Texas is not as glowing as Bush portrays; there are equally tense exchanges between Bush and Sen John McCain in last Republican debate before New Hampshire primary; Gary L Bauer and Alan Keyes also take part in debate; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: When Dr. Allan Zarkin came looking for work, Merle Hoffman could not have been happier. She and the doctor had worked together off and on for many years in her clinic, Choices Women's Medical Center in Queens. Moreover, her medical director had just left, so she happily handed the title over to Dr. Zarkin on Nov. 1. What she said she did not know was that the doctor had been dismissed just weeks before from Beth Israel Medical Center for what may be the most bizarre incident in the history of the hospital.

headline.main: How Doctor Got Work After Carving Into Patient

docs.abstract: Article discusses how Dr Allan Zarkin was able to find employment at abortion clinic after being dismissed from Beth Israel Medical Center for carving his initials into stomach of patient on whom he had just performed Caesarean section; patient, Dr Liana Gedz, is suing hospital, Dr Zarkin and his former medical practice for $5.5 million; photo (M)
docs.snippet: When Dr. Allan Zarkin came looking for work, Merle Hoffman could not have been happier. She and the doctor had worked together off and on for many years in her clinic, Choices Women's Medical Center in Queens. Moreover, her medical director had just...

byline.original: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER and EDWARD WONG

docs.lead_paragraph: An obstetrician who carved his initials into a woman's abdomen at Beth Israel Medical Center after delivering her first baby in September worked for two months at a Queens women's clinic performing abortions after being dismissed from both the hospital and his former practice, the clinic's president said yesterday. The obstetrician, Dr. Allan Zarkin, was hired last November by the Choices Women's Medical Center in Long Island City, Queens, to perform abortions and general gynecological care, including prenatal exams, said Merle Hoffman, the clinic's president. At that time, the State Department of Health had already begun an inquiry into Dr. Zarkin's treatment of previous patients, including Dr. Liana Gedz, 31, the carving victim.

headline.main: Doctor in Carving Case Soon Had New Job

docs.abstract: Dr Allan Zarkin, obstetrician who carved his initials into woman's abdomen at Beth Israel Medical Center after delivering her first baby in September, reportedly worked for two months at a Queens women's clinic performing abortions after being dismissed from both hospital and his former practice (S)

docs.abstract: In this lesson, students explore the impact of smoking in various workplaces. Acting as the owners and managers of different types of business locations, students develop smoking policies and defend them by responding to students portraying smoking and non-smoking patrons and employees.

docs.lead_paragraph: THE drumbeat of good economic news is becoming so familiar that the nation might be excused for taking its prosperity for granted. The United States enjoys the lowest unemployment rate in a generation, stratospheric stock markets, stable prices and even reduced welfare rolls. But with the current economic expansion about to become the longest on record, there are other, less salutary numbers worth reflecting on. They suggest that those at the bottom of the economic ladder are not benefiting much from the boom and, by some measures, are falling even farther behind.

headline.main: The Nation; In a Time of Plenty, The Poor Are Still Poor

docs.abstract: National economy continues to extend its longest period of sustained growth, but poverty persists; figures suggest that those at bottom of economic ladder are not benefiting from boom and, by some measures, are falling even farther behind; degree of problem remains subject to debate, but some analysts see it as potential threat to economy's long-term prospects; conservatives are joining liberals in acknowledging that gap between rich and poor matters; photo; graphs (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: As insurance fraud cases go, the federal government's case against Dr. Niels H. Lauersen is far from typical. Dr. Lauersen, a well-known Manhattan gynecologist and fertility expert, did not deal with Medicare or Medicaid, the government insurance programs that often attract fraudulent billing schemes. And prosecutors acknowledge that unlike doctors in most medical fraud cases, who bill for procedures that never took place or for patients who do not exist, Dr. Lauersen treated real patients for real conditions, treatments they were desperately seeking.

headline.main: Fraud Case Underscores Debate on Paying for Infertility Care

docs.abstract: Health insurance fraud trial of Dr Nils H Lauersen, well-known Manhattan gynecologist and fertility expert, opens new territory for health fraud cases; Lauersen is accused of billing insurance companies for routine gynecological procedures to cover fertility surgeries for women who could not otherwise get pregnant; law enforcement officials say that over course of 10 years, Lauersen submitted hundreds of false bills amounting to roughly $4 million; photo (M)
